abstract: pmc Cancer Cell Int Cancer Cell Int 96 cancell Cancer Cell International 1475-2867 BMC PMC12495670 PMC12495670.1 12495670 12495670 41044749 10.1186/s12935-025-03983-9 3983 1 Comment Oncovirus classification and insights into herpes simplex virus, Varicella-Zoster virus Ghaemi Amir ghaem_amir@yahoo.com a_ghaemi@pasteur.ac.ir Sadeh Sanaz https://ror.org/00wqczk30 grid.420169.8 0000 0000 9562 2611 Department of Influenza and Respiratory Viruses, Research Centre for Emerging and Reemerging Infectious Diseases, Pasteur Institute of Iran, 3 10 2025 2025 25 478344 331 8 10 2024 6 9 2025 03 10 2025 05 10 2025 05 10 2025 © The Author(s) 2025 2025 https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/ Open Access http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/ Even though the paper entitled: The role of oncolytic virotherapy and viral oncogenes in the cancer stem cells: a review of virus in cancer stem cells” provides informative details regarding viral contribution in cancer biology, its classification of Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) and Varicella-Zoster Virus (VZV) as oncoviruses is inaccurate. Current evidence demonstrates that while HSV and VZV may reactivate in immunocompromised cancer patients, there is no causative relationship between these two viruses and oncogenesis. It is necessary to make a distinction between cancer-inducing viruses and reactivated viruses due to immune suppression among cancer patients. Keywords Herpes simplex virus Varicella-Zoster virus Oncovirus Tumorigenesis Reactivation National Institute for Medical Research Development (NIMAD) 962110 Ghaemi Amir pmc-status-qastatus 0 pmc-status-live yes pmc-status-embargo no pmc-status-released yes pmc-prop-open-access yes pmc-prop-olf no pmc-prop-manuscript no pmc-prop-legally-suppressed no pmc-prop-has-pdf yes pmc-prop-has-supplement no pmc-prop-pdf-only no pmc-prop-suppress-copyright no pmc-prop-is-real-version no pmc-prop-is-scanned-article no pmc-prop-preprint no pmc-prop-in-epmc yes issue-copyright-statement © BioMed Central Ltd., part of Springer Nature 2025 To the editor, We read with great interest an article published in Cancer Cell International by Faghihkhorasani and colleagues entitled: The role of oncolytic virotherapy and viral oncogenes in the cancer stem cells: a review of virus in cancer stem cells. The manuscript presents an interesting view on the dual role of viruses in the biology of cancer stem cell (CSC). It explains the mechanism through which oncogenic viruses such as human papillomavirus (HPV), hepatitis C virus (HCV), and Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) promote tumor initiation and development by the induction of CSC-like properties. These viruses have oncoproteins that disrupt cellular homeostasis by immortalizing the cell and tumor growth. Furthermore, the potential of oncolytic viruses (OVs) to selectively infect and kill CSCs and non-CSCs is promising for the treatment of cancer. By review of the contradictory roles of viruses in tumorigenesis and as a strategy for cancer therapy, the article offers the possibility of utilizing viral mechanisms for therapeutic advantage [ 1 The article mentions that “The major oncoviruses are Epstein–Barr virus, hepatitis B virus (HBV), HCV, mastadenovirus, aviadenovirus, rhadinovirus, varicellovirus, polyomavirus, adenoviruses, orthopoxvirus, leporipoxvirus, parvovirus, human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), HPV, human herpesvirus 8, and simplex virus which induce uncontrolled cell growth by a common way of interfering with the tumor p53 gene”. However, the inclusion of Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) and varicellovirus (Varicella-Zoster Virus, VZV) as oncoviruses needs clarification. HSV and VZV are not classified as tumor viruses or oncoviruses. Oncoviruses are defined as viruses that directly induce cancer by inserting their oncogenes into host cells, driving oncogenic transformation. Recent studies indicate that although HSV infections are common among immunosuppressed cancer patients, no conclusive evidence exists for a direct involvement of HSV in cancer induction [ 2 3 4 5 2 Similarly, the VZV, which is responsible for causing herpes zoster (HZ), reactivates mostly in immunocompromised individuals, i.e., cancer patients or those who have undergone hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HCT). Reactivation rates of VZV reach as high as 63% in certain populations with cancer [ 6 7 Importantly, within the herpesvirus family, only EBV, KSHV, and more recently Human Cytomegalovirus (HCMV) are supported by evidence as oncogenic viruses. Notably, cutting-edge research indicates that some high-risk HCMV strains possess malignant transforming potential and may contribute to tumor progression by reprogramming the tumor microenvironment and influencing CSC biology in the central nervous system [ 8 In conclusion, the article’s claim of HSV and VZV as oncoviruses is unsupported by reliable sources and may mislead readers.
